remixed_from.author: garyacrowellsr
remixed_from.title: Replicator/FF Y-Shaft Pillow Block, with drill guide

title: FlashForge Creator Pillow Block EZ install

description.text:
This modification of Crowell's pillow block adds a slot in the base such that once the bearings are slipped onto the shafts, the pillow blocks can be inserted or removed without disturbing the shafts or pulleys or alignment (much).
Two slight ridges are used to hold the bearings in place, such that flexing the pillow block should be enough to free the bearing for insertion or removal.
This makes it much easier to experiment with slight changes to pillow block dimensions or designs.

I liked Gary Crowell's design, but I wasn't sure about the optimum dimensions for my printer, so it occurred to me it would be easy to experiment and adjust if I just put a gap in the base so I could install or remove the pillow block without having to remove the bearing from the shaft! To install bearings on a FlashForge Creator, just loosen the pulleys and slip the shaft to the right a few inches.
Slip two 5x11x4 bearings onto the shaft, then slide it to the left through the left pulley and the left sleeve, then into the left outside bearing. (I put 3 bearings on, not being sure whether I'd want a mid-point pillow too.)
With practice (or maybe a little clamp) one can keep the belt engaged with the floating pulley, which simplifies getting the setscrews positioned for convenient tightening (if they were convenient before, that is).
Do this for both the front and the back shafts.
Now you can follow the usual procedure to get the setscrews tight and the carriage parallel to the front panel, then slip a pillow block (with nuts in their slots) over the shaft and pop a bearing into it, spreading the bottom slightly to slip it past the Bearing Hold Ridges. Clamp it in place, and drill two 2mm bolt holes using the pillow nuts as a guide. From the outside, enlarge those holes to 3mm (or larger, to allow some motion for alignment adjustments) and bolt the pillow in place.
I suspect it's sufficient to add 2 pillow blocks/bearings to each shaft, positioned fairly near the pulleys.
On my original FlashForge Creator, the shaft was bowing 4-5mm, and the curvature and resultant flexing probably caused the pulley setscrews to work loose, which they did several times, and made them click too.
So even if the pillow blocks aren't perfectly aligned, it's still got to be far better than the original setup!
DBG

comments.text: Eliminated a huge wobble in my Flashforge using two of these. Thanks!
comments.author: betamax

comments.text: What type of screw and nut does this use? I need to go buy more so i can install this asap :P mine bows quite a bit
comments.author: dantheflipman

comments.text: How did you install the front pillow blocks? I installed the pillow blocks on either side of the bot, where the triangle-fillets were on the frame, but the center still appears to be bowing by about 2mm.
comments.author: hyperair

comments.text:
I'm not sure 2mm is enough to bother with...
In my case, I installed 4 pillow blocks, one in each of the triangle fillets, 2 in back and 2 in front. For me the front blocks were a hair short, so they made the shaft bow toward the front a little, the reverse of the original situation. I just loosened the screws a bit and it seems close enough, but I could insert a sheet of paper as a shim if having a more solid mount seems worthwhile.
If the blocks are too tall, by just a hair, you might try sanding them a little.
Anyway, I have the impression that putting a block in the center isn't necessary as long as the two blocks are close to the right height and near the pulleys. They made a big improvement in the creaking and clicking noises, and I expect they've eliminated the problem of the pulley setscrews working loose. It's easy to see how the original setup, with a bending rod writhing through the pulleys, would move the setscrews!
comments.author: hyperair

comments.text: Oddly enough, I printed one with the wrong dimensions (turns out the width of my bearings are 5.2mm, and I measured ShaftDist wrongly the first time around, setting it to 16mm instead of 15.5mm). They did help a lot with the noise, but I've been noticing a little bit of clicking from time to time as the belts try to ride up the sides of the pulleys. I'm also seeing quite a bit of black dust around that area, presumably as the pulley walls grind the belt down.

Dubbed jokingly the "LesterBot", this printer is little more than an XY table with a swiveled glass cutter moving over a glass surface, etching in a pattern that grows deeper with time.  Topological features are possible to accomplish, making it a limited form of a 3D printer.  
Other materials, cutters, or deposition heads may be fitted if they are light enough.  The motors are plastic and also act as the bearings for the rollers, which accept bands of the correct length.  
The control is frequency to position mapped audio on the left=x and right=y channels out of the stereo jack of any mp3 player, phone, or computer.  GCode is converted to musical frequencies by a custom written program.  
Power is provided through USB cable from computer, phone, or battery pack.  Audio frequency to servo position conversion is done by three ATtiny85 Arduino processors which only cost $2.50 each.  
With this simplified printer one can make many things, yet the parts are either printable or scroungeable.  This makes it a perfect third world printer, one that any student with access to a 3D printer can assemble themselves.  It may even be possible to etch the parts for another printer on this printer (maybe)...

comments.text: OK, I posted the two source code files for the test arduino setup.  The Controller sends pulses to the Driver which converts the pulses to rotor signal applications via the output opamps.  That's all the electronics for now.  Later the Controller will be replaced with the computer which will send a stream of audio for frequency to position mapping and following of GCode.  See my things for the stepper motor design that goes with this.  Sorry to cause any frustration, not my intention to do that.  Just early in the process.
comments.author: charleshood97

comments.text: I'll bite.  What's a ATtiny85 Arduiono?
comments.author: Arvin

comments.text: The ATTiny is an 8 pin Atmel chip. You can add support for many of them into the Arduino IDE and write standard Arduino code, then upload it to these other chips. Google on "Arduino on other Atmel" for more info there. You have MUCH less memory, obviously, and not as many pins, but for many projects you don't need a full blown (and large) 328 chip. So, while not technically an "ATTiny85 Arduino" the end result is the same. ;)
comments.author: Arvin

comments.text: An ATtiny85 is an eight pin Arduino processor chip.  It is great for programming to do simple functions like this.
comments.author: Arvin

comments.text: Oh, I thought somebody had made a new version. You spelled it "Ardui"+"ono". I already have a couple of Adafruit's Trinkets which are attiny85's. Was hoping for another one. :)
comments.author: deltaModulator

comments.text: I fixed the spelling error, thank you.  The role of the ATTiny85 in this system is to convert frequency to position, then issue stepper commands that walk to that position.  The program will store the position as zero on reset, then when a tone is received it will proceed to walk the stepper to the position that corresponds to that tone.  The stereo right and left channels will drive the X and Y rollers respectively.  Opamps do the coil driving at the command of the two ATtiny85 outputs.  That's it for the smarts of this thing, it's pretty dumb on purpose.  You can even record a print as an mp3 file.
comments.author: Arvin

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WTK5fVQNPsI Plater is an open-source 3D printer plates placer and optimizer. It takes a few STL files and some parameters such as the plate dimension, part orientation and spacing, and it tries to generates 3D model(s) to print your parts with at least as possible plates.
It uses a really simple configuration file (plater.conf) that contains the list of parts with their quantities and dimension. You can then build your STL plate(s) and release it with your part, or simply release the plater.conf file and let people do their own plates using their own settings.

• Get Windows binaries (v1.0)
  • Get Linux binaries (v1.0), Qt 4.8 and OpenGL required
  • Get OSX dmg (v1.0), thanks to Toby Tomkins

    Sources and repository

  • Plater on GitHub

title: 1st Bicycle with Crankset or Trike 3d printed on a Replicator!
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Remember when you were a kid and you had all that fun playing on a big plastic trike? You might be surprised to find that this is it, 3d printed. It will have egg beater pedals directly mounted on the front wheel without a chain, zero brakes, and 100 percent fun! For middle aged kids and little kids, everyone will have fun on this trike! I invite you to visit my website for more cool and unique things: 3dPrintFileMarket.com. This is more than just another 3d printing site. It is the home of the original technology accelerator app. It will render the old way of developing and sharing technology as obsolete as digital media has rendered vinyl records obsolete. If you were to fall asleep today and wake up 10 years later, I guarantee that you will not even recognize the world we live in any more. You'll swear you woke up on another planet. Welcome to the 21st century ;0)

Print it on its side with supports. This is the first instalment of a series of prints to be posted on my website culminating in a fully ride-able trike in a couple of months. This is designed to print easily on a Rep Rap style FDM 3d printer. Printed at 80 percent fill, including printed breakaway supports, it uses 1 kg of ABS. If you have the Makerbot 2kg spools of ABS, you may print this at 100 percent fill with 1.25 kg of ABS. Alternately, you may use file negative6.stl to print soluble supports for zero clean-up if you have a dual extruder machine such as a Replicator 1. Future instalments will be posted on the 3d Print File Market . Enjoy ;0)

description.text: 6.2 cm footed bowl, simple design made with Rhino 3D 4.0, scaled to 80% as an stl code.  It is certainly not leakproof but could be made closer to leak reistsant with a slightly increased thickness.  I am including the gcode as this would probably be a good print for beginners.

STL code generated with Rhino3D 4.0, then the gcode made with the embedded Skeinforge in ReplicatorG version 17 which seems to make more economical builds with better rafts.  However, I printed this (on a build 12 Cupcake CNC with Plastruder MK4 using Cakeller98's excellent mod to prevent extruder insanity) using ReplicatorG 16 as printing on 17 led to seemingly random hiccups along the way.

title: Prusa Mendel Zero Z Wobble Upgrade

description.text: This modification will greatly reduce or completely eliminate your z wobble issue, and it will only cost you about $3.

This modification has reduced my z wobble to nothing.  The M8 leadscrews are far too stiff and will affect the X carriage in unwanted ways.  10-24 threaded rod is much more flexible and will affect the X carriage much less. 
Vitamins you'll need for this modification are two 295mm lengths of 10-24 threaded rod, eight 10-24 hex nuts and two 10-24 washers,  two compression springs that will fit over the rod, and four short lengths of 1/8"ID 1/4"OD vinyl tubing.  For the clamps you'll need eight M3x20 screws and nuts or 4-40x0.75" screws and nuts.
Print four of the 10-24 to M8 adapters and two sets of the coupling clamp.
Slide 10-15mm piece of vinyl tubing onto the end of your stepper shaft and another piece onto the end of the threaded rod.  
The side of the rod with the vinyl tubing is the top.  
Press the 10-24 hex nuts into the 10-24 to M8 adapters,  screw one adapter onto the rod with the 10-24 hex nut facing up,  slide the spring over the rod and insert the rod and adapter into the x carriage support.  Compress the spring and screw the other nut adapter on the rod with the 10-24 nut facing down, screw up into the x carriage support so the spring has some compression on it.  Screw on two additional 10-24 nuts and then a washer and tighten the two nuts together at the base of the z lead screw.
Your new z axis steps per millimeter is 3023.62 steps/mm assuming you are using 16x microstepping.
You can see my before and after z wobble form the picture of the blue pink panther woman and the red cylinder.  The pink panther woman was one of my first prints and you can see considerable z wobble, the red cylinder was my first print after the modification and you can see there is practically zero z wobble.
The patriotic red, white and blue pink panther women are all printed with pla. The blue one was printed before swapping my lead screws. The white one was printed with the new lead screws with some white pla that I believe had absorbed to much moisture and has some serious layer smash issues.  The red was printed with the new lead screws and also has some layer smash issues but the z wobble is obviously greatly improved from the old M8 leadscrews.
These parts were made in SolidWorks and repaired in Netfabb to ensure they are perfectly manifold.

title: Z-Mounts with Increased Y-Gap for Box-Frame Prusa i3

description.text: For a standard Prusa i3, the gap behind Z-axis is very tight, so that in my case the rear of the X-carriage collides with the frame as I try to move it out further than the main cut-out - limiting this way my maximum possible printing volume. The same also happens if one tries to use an extruder motor which is longer than 43mm. While this problem is easy to correct for a single sheet frame (just "lift" the corners by putting some "spacer" between the Z-mounts and the frame), the problem is more difficult to remedy for a box-frame, since simply "lifting" the corners away from the XZ-plane will also move the lateral screw holes away from the center, not leaving enough (if any) space for a secure hold of the side screws... For this reason, I decided to make my own design of the Z-mounts with an additional parameter used to specify an extra Y-gap in mm. If this parameter is 0, the mounts will have the same gap as the Prusa's original i3 mounts, whereas e.g. a value of 5 would move the entire Z- and X-axes 5mm further away from the box frame. The relative positions of the front and side screws (which are used to attach the mount to the box-frame) are compatible with the original Prusa i3 mounts, so that these new mounts can be used to replace the original ones using the existing screw holes. The provided SCAD file is fully parametrized and can thus be easily adapted to any special requirement. I also include some "ready-to-print" STL files for extra Y-gaps between 0mm and 5mm and for box-frame board thicknesses of 12mm, 15mm and 18mm. PS: As you can see from my pictures, I prefer to use the Z-mounts "upside down" compared to the original Prusa i3, so that no screws are hidden behind the Z-motors. But of course, this is a matter of taste and you can my mounts just as well in the "traditional" orientation with the flat part on top. Update 2014-10-25: I have uploaded an enhanced version of the SCAD file and some STL files which also include a holder for a Z-endstop slider. on the left motor mount. This can be used with my Split X-ends for Prusa i3. The slider arms are taken from my Sliding Y-Endstop Mount for Prusa i3, where you can also find the corresponding SCAD source.

A derivative of Johann's Rostock but using 80/20 1010 T-Slotted aluminum instead of smooth SS rods. The extruded aluminum provide support for the prism structure. Video: http://youtu.be/STc54aOQdK4 The goal for my derivative of the Johannâ€™s Rostock was to build a simpler, lighter and more robust structure. I decided to use extruded aluminum since itâ€™s quite strong, readily available, and relatively inexpensive. A piece of 80/20 10 SERIES 1010 1" X 1" T-SLOTTED EXTRUSION x 72" (1828.8mm) sells for $19 in Amazon.com. I was also inclined to use aluminum given that I have previous experience building and fabricating with this material (I built an all aluminum airplane in my garage). Gone are all the wood parts, and the stainless steel rods. I kept the idea of using as many 3D printed parts as possible, since I had easy access to a friendâ€™s Prusa Mendel printer. I am a software developer; hence it was easy for me to learn OpenSCAD to design my own parts. I tried to keep the number of new parts to a minimum and, if possible, reuse or make a derivative of the original Rostock parts. I studied the Rostock Max by SeeMeCNC, which I think it is awesome. I love the â€œCheapskateâ€ design so I tried to replicate it but instead of flat plates for the carriage I decided to modify Johannâ€™s design to fit the profile of the 1010 and to accommodate four 608 bearings. After multiple iterations and head scratching sessions, I concluded that the best and easiest way to provide anti-backlash pressure between the bearings and the channel was to elongate the shaft holes and wrap a rubber band between the opposing M4 bolts serving as bearing shafts. It works beautifully. Another difference is in the track of the GT2 belt. On the Max, the belt in the back of the carriage tracks within the 1010 slot. On the other side of the carriage, the belt tracks a few millimeters parallel to the 1010 beam. On the PRISMA, the whole length of the belt, up and down segments, track within the inward facing slot of the 1010 beam. Thereâ€™s a separation of approximately 3mm between the up and down moving segments of the belt. The separation is made possible by the double bearing idler design. One bearing pushes one segment of the belt inward into the channel while the other keeps the top belt tracking just above and flush with the edges of the channel. The only drawback to this approach was that it requires you to widen 1.5â€ (38mm) of the channel at the top and bottom to allow the 608 bearing to fit inside the slot in order to push the belt farther in. You can easily accomplish this task with a Dremel rotary tool, metal cutting tool, small sanding tool and a flat screwdriver. The three vertical sections of 1010 extrusion provide the support for the entire structure. I used my cheap compound miter saw with a $12 metal cutting blade to cut the extruded aluminum pieces. I cut the vertical pieces to 36â€ ( 914.4mm). This translates to a maximum build height of roughly 13â€ (330mm). You can increase the build height by using longer verticals, however you need to keep in mind that you will need longer GT2 belts. The horizontal aluminum pieces are sandwiched in between top and bottom plastic corner gussets at each end and secured with t-nuts. You can buy 80/20 t-nuts at $0.24 a piece or you can make your own by printing a bunch or tnut.stl copies and super gluing a regular 10-32 nut to the plastic. The final structure is a triangular/prism beam very straight, clean and sturdy. Lastly, all other parts hang from the aluminum extrusion; motor mounts, heated bed, idlers, electronics, power supply, etc. I design and printed special mounting clips that fit the 1010 profile.

Since some of you ask, here is an initial BOM. Remember this is still WIP. Some items in the list might (and probably will) change. I will be making minor mods to the carriage, bearing clip, and extruder parts. More instructions, files and pictures will be added soon. Bill of Material

comments.text: The 80/20 10 Series is a T slotted aluminum extrusion.  Each slot (channel) is approx. 6mm deep by 6mm wide.  I wanted to keep the printer clean so the channel looked like the perfect place to hide the GT2 belt.   On the PRISMA the vertical extrusion serves as the carriage beam and the leg of the printer.  This presented a problem if I were to route the GT2 belt up and around the carriage beam through the back and inner channels. Therefore I decided to route the belt through the inner channel only (the one facing the heat bed).  In this configuration I have 2 pieces of the belt riding in the same channel. Hence, I needed a way to create separation between the 2 pieces.  That is the purpose of the the double bearing idler.  The first bearings pushes the inner side of the belt deep into the channel while the second bearing keeps the outer side of the belt riding flush with the edges of the channel.  Important caveat however, since the  608ZZ bearing is slightly wider than the width of the mouth of the channel you will need to widen the channel edges so that the bearing clears the edges and is able to push the inner belt deep into the channel.  Also note that you need 2 idlers, top and bottom, for each belt.  Hope this helps.  Happy building.

comments.text: At the top of the printer, attached to the bottom of each one of the idlers is a small microswitch, the mechanical end stops.  The printer uses them for calculating the Home position.  I used 3M double sided tape to hold them in place.  The raised area on the back of the top carriage has a small hole at the top that is meant for a 10mm M3 screw.  Just screw the M3 into the hole and it will self tap.  When you issue the Home command the carriage moves up and stops when the head of the screw hits the microswitch. You use the screw to make fine adjustments during calibration.   If when you Home your printer for the first time, the carriages move down instead of up, you will need to change a setting in the firmware Configuration.h file to reverse the travel.  I belive the value is ENDSTOPS_INVERTING = false on all 3 axes (XYZ).

Hi all. Â Here is a list of new updates:
Â  Â 1) I changed the carriage to use two 608ZZ per axle instead of one. Â The 608s now ride on the flat at each side of the channel instead of the channel edges. Â This required an extra 1mm on each side of the carriage.
Â  Â 2) The axle is was modified for the new configuration.
Â  Â 3) Added a spacer to the idlerClips to keep a consistent 6mm gap between each idler clip.
Â  Â 4) I uploaded the new STL files and made changes to the BOM.

comments.text: I am still having print quality issues. Â I did discover a carriage design issue. Â It didn't take that long for the ball bearings to wear away the thin edge of aluminum channel. Â The bearings got stuck on the channel. Â I modified the carriage to use 8 bearings instead of 4; Â two in each side of the channel. Â So the bearings will ride on the flat sided instead of the thin edges of the channel. Â I am currently printing the new carriage and should be able to test in a few days. Â I will upload the mods as soon as I get it tested. Â Another problem for me has been setting the right amount of retraction. Â The Bowden tube creates a delayed reaction which makes the retraction difficult to set. Â I get lots of hanging material when at travel points and inside of holes. Â I'll keep you all posted.Â

At the request of my eldest daughter I printed a Happy face.  I didn't check here first to find if anyone else did one since I was showing my kid how the whole process works start to end.  Of course it took 8 tries with Green ABS to get the thing to print.  The biggest challenge I ran into was the behavior of the green was nothing like what I'd printed in natural ABS.
Anyhow, give it a try, I hope to see a few of these in other colors (I may do a couple myself, byt if anyone else has a go GREAT!

Mostly Standard 3D print on Makerbot cupcake. I Used green filament ABS but had some challenges... In skeinforge I carved the 0.30mm layer thickness, which required that the feed rate increased to 32mm/s and the Extrusion PWM was set at 245. There was still a bit too much plastic being extruded. and the finish ended up being a bit dodgy. On my next go I'm going to up the feed speed to 36mm/s and maybe reduce the plastruder PWM to 240. I left all the other Skeinforge settings the same as recommended on the makerbot wiki page for skeinforge. If you have a chance to use this setting combo and to works out for you, please let me know. Or if you find a better combination, I'd love to hear about it. June 25/'10 Update:
Increasing feedrate to 36mm/s and reducing plastruder speed to 240PWM worked really well. Check out the new Red Happy face image. After 3 failed attempts to get the raft to stick, I was able to get the red print done.

comments.text: If you get too much plastic all around (vs only on the perimeter or only  in the fill), I'd turn the feedrate up a little instead of turning the flowrate down. Or, same idea, if you get too little plastic all around, slow the feedrate down instead of speeding up the flowrate.

Assemble the frame with some parts from old Soviet Konstructor toy (pretty much the same as Erector Set). Assemble printed arms with six M3x12 bolts. Screw 24BYJ48 (or any similar) stepper motor to the frame and connect it to your Arduino board. Drop M4 nuts into nut traps, place a spacer between two nut traps, then fasten this assembly to the frame right above motor shaft. Screw M4 threaded rod into place and put printed table on the top of it.
Have fun!

One neat thing I noticed is that my printer need a recalibration. The sign came at a slight angle so i have to re align it. Having this sign as a calibration piece was not intended that's for sure.

title: 3D-printed Conformations of Knots through 7 Crossings
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Knots are embeddings of circles in 3-dimensional space, but they are typically studied in terms of their projections into 2-dimensional space. We can use 3D printing to study knots in a more 3-dimensional way. In this series we present 3D printed conformations of the fifteen knots through seven crossings, including stick, Lissajous, lattice, torus, petal, and pretzel conformations. Constructing a 3D knot model that is actually printable can challenging; to 3D print the knot conformations through seven crossings, we used a combination of Mathematica, Blender, Tinkercad, Knotplot, SeifertView, and OpenSCAD. For detailed information about the mathematics and the design behind these models, see the MakerHome blog: 0_1 at Day 267
3_1 at Day 268
4_1 at Day 269
5_1 at Day 272

title: iPad Mini Charging Dock / Stand Made from Apple Parts

description.text:
I was frustrated yesterday that there is not a desktop dock / stand and had 10 minutes to spare.
All parts are Apple made parts save for the super glue and 3M tape.
I took a regular iPad dock, set the ban saw to its width. Cut a piece of acrylic to that width. The acrylic was from some old iPod packaging, masked that piece for a notch out for the 30 pin to Lightning connector, cut that out with a Dremel tool, adhered the adapter with 3M tape, then ran a bead of Loctite Super Glue Gel control along the top edge of the white dock. BINGO! iPad Mini Dock / Charging stand. Problem solved.

description.text:
I have a Xperia SP and looking for stands on the internet I saw lots of people wanted one of this stand made by Sony, so i just made one for printing! =]
Idea was taken from the website below.
http://www.xperiablog.net/2012/12/10/we-want-this-xperia-x-phone-stand/ The last revision has a thinner channel for the cellphone to fit and a small base for the phone to lay, this way it won't slip from the stand. On the old revision, the channel was wider and the phone was slipping through, another reason is the plastic that is too light, with these corrections it won't happen anymore. Printed in my BRbot Tower 3d Printer.
Please visit:
http://www.brbot.com.br/impressora-3d-tower-3d.html

You can print it the way it is to get a best finish on the Xperia word. This way you have a bridge. If you prefer, turn it around facing the printer bed.  
Use support for better printing. Slic3r support config: 3mm spacing and 1 interface layer.

remixed_from.title: printable glowing in the dark space shuttle

description.text:
Another item for intended for givaways at airshows, maker fairs & science events. Printed at 0.5 scale. I added a thicker tailfin (for the smaller scale) to limit snapping it off, and rocket exhausts.   
No support or raft required for the scale printed at. The rocket exhausts might need support if printed larger - I deliberately did not extend them out too far to get away without support at a smaller scale.  
The source for the remix was from BonsaiBrain, Thanks!
3mm PLA @ 200 Centigrade. Sliced 0.3mm with 25% fill. Printed at 0.5 scale. I used a small brass brush to get rid of the stringy PLA fluff after printing them off four at a time.

This is a basic j head mount to be screwed on to the existing hotend plate. This is the nondestructive approach, no metal work required and you only loose a 1-2cm in Y.
It fits now into my E3D V6 hotend and it dimensioned a bit to big to ensure a snug fit. V4 update: I added a little plate to hold a fan funnel (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:494430). Its screws in with the part that holds the hotend in place.

The mounting plate can be screwed in with M2.5 screws in the upper to holes in the Y carriage.
Depending on the length of the hotend the mounting plate should be adjusted so that the nozzle ends ~5mm under the X carriage.
The available height in the mounting plate should include most hotends.
The clamp the holds the hotend in place uses 2x M3x30 screws.

title: E3D V6 HotEnd CAD Models (Includes all 3 versions)

description.text:
Three 3D models of the most recently released E3D V6 Hotend: The 1.75mm Universal Version, The 3.00mm Bowden Version, and The 3.00mm Direct HotEnd Version. These models don't have any of the inner details (mainly because those weren't in the drawings, but also because that seems unnecessary), so these are mainly intended for anyone who wants to design a mount or just get an idea for the space it takes up in different orientations. If anyone finds anything wrong with my measurements, please let me know in the comments and I'll update my design accordingly.
***Note: This is an updated version from what I had previously, the 1.75mm universal version is identical to what it was before besides a slight name change to make keeping track of the different versions of the hot end easier, the main change is only that this now includes CAD files for both the 3.00mm versions in addition to the 1.75mm version for anyone who might want a CAD model for the exact version that they plan on using.

title: Wall Mount for iPad
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a wall mountable and VESA compatible wall mount for the Apple iPad and iPad 3G.
I'd LOVE to see your versions.  I have cut the Walet out of bamboo (Plyboo), birch plywood, and Corian already and it looks beautiful in all kinds of materials.  I think an acrylic one would be really cool.

FRONT:
Cut the front face-down using a CNC machine using 3/4" material. The pocket should be cut .606 deep. We use a 1/4" compression bit for the nicest finish on Plyboo. Sand exterior surfaces and headphone access port. BACK:
Cut the back face-down using a CNC machine using 1/2" thick material. The holes should be drilled at the appropriate diameter for your M4 screw inserts. These holes are spaced for 75mm x 75mm VESA compatibility. If you can generate a keyhole toolpath, use the outer circles as your plunge start. I suggest allowing for a 1/8" wall at a minimum if you are using a wood/grass material. Sand interior side. Edit: insert iPad so that the squircle button is on the right... ;-) FOAM INSERT:
Cut out your foam insert using some kind of self adhesive foam. We use laser cutter but you could easily one-off this part with some scissors and a utility knife. Note: we apply masking material to the foam prior to cutting and remove it after the final finishing step. ASSEMBLY:
  • Apply foam insert to front.
  • Glue front to back (avoid squeeze-out!).
  • Sand to 400 grit, apply a suitable finish. We hand-apply a natural oil-based finish for the bamboo Walet as it brings out the natural beauty of the grass.
  • Install M4 inserts in VESA mounting holes
  • Take a photo and send it to us at <a mailto:"[email protected]">[email protected]!
    • If you cut the keyholes print the attached mounting template on 8.5 x 11" paper to make things a little easier. More photos and information available at http://www.waletmount.com

title: Low-Poly Totodile
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I would love to keep sharing my projects with all of you. If you enjoy with my designs, I invite you to become a patron, you will get early access to my designs and exclusive content! Also, you can help with a small donation. Patreon: http://www.patreon.com/flowalistik
Donations: http://www.paypal.me/flowalistik

NOTE: You can check my newest designs in my YouMagine profile! More Low-Poly and other simple designs! https://www.youmagine.com/users/flowalistik Designing a low-poly Pokemon is the best way I found to represent the poor graphic quality the first Pokemon games had. So, here I present you the low-poly Totodile, which is part of the Low-Poly project I'm developing. 3D printers allow to make real the idea of catching all Pokemon, and I'm currently working to make all the Pokemon I can. You can check the collection in the following page: http://www.thingiverse.com/FLOWALISTIK/collections/low-poly-pokemon This model is 5cm tall approximately. The model from the picture was printed with a Prusa i3, 0.2mm layer height, 0.5mm nozzle, 45mm/s speed and a cooling fan (I really recommend this!). The material is 3mm high quality PLA. It was designed so it doesn't need support material, although each printer is different and it may be more difficult to print it depending on the settings. // This design is based on Pokemon

author: Riallywood

description.text: ... to hang stuff on sheetrock walls.

Sheetrock / wallboard / plasterboard / drywall / hanger / anchor. Prints differ from injection molding in many ways. They have distinct directional weakness and layers are split easily. Prints also lack flexibility. Many tried and true molded-part designs don't translate well to 3D prints. This 2-piece anchor attempts to take advantage of a print's strengths while minimizing weaknesses. The tapered core expands the shell. The screw provides longitudinal strength to the assembly.
Coarse (0.30 mm Z) layering seems to be an advantage. The bumpiness in adjacent surfaces helps lock the parts together. The anchor was tested in 5/8" rock but should be OK with regular household 1/2 inch... It might be best to try it in a clothes closet first so nobody notices the damage. Drill a 5/16 inch (8 mm) hole. Push the shell into the hole (probably need a hammer). Align and insert the core (gonna need the hammer again). Then drive in the screw.
Standard 1.25" "fine" thread drywall screws seem best.They are thin, hardened and strong. Photo shows a 15 lb (7 kilo) dumbbell hanging from a wire. I gently let that go fearing it would pull out but the anchor can actually support more weight. I'd never hang a heavy weight except to test it and was not too interested in exactly how much more, so quit while I was ahead. Removal: First remove the core with a thin, stiff blade so the shell contracts and it can be removed. [EDIT My mistake. The core's head just breaks off if you try to remove it like that. Instead, back out the screw part of the way, protect the wall and use a claw hammer to remove screw + core. Then the shell can be removed.] Printing 6 units (12 pieces) required ~40 minutes and 10 grams ABS using Afinia defaults: 0.30 Z, medium speed and fill with a raft. Printing several at one time did eliminate the need for fan-cooling.
Carefully separate rafts to preserve the little shoulders on the parts.

description.text: This Locket is based on the locket from the movie "The Illusionist". Here's the scene: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nvKWNyp5bbI Basically there are 8 pieces, a custom made axel (made with a paper clip and small bead), and then a straight axel (also a paper clip). It is held together by small 2 mm diameter x 1 mm deep circular magnets and epoxy. The pieces fit together to form 4 layers. The middle 2 layers are stuck together using the epoxy while the top and bottom layers are held on by the magnets. Here is a video I made explaining more about how it works and how it's held together. I gave some tips for making it in the video as well. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FkYwnJAkRJM Keep in mind that this was a gift and could definitely be improved if given more time but this was a first draft. The locket was designed so that it fit my axel, one would have to recreate my axel or else change the cut out for the axel in the middle layer.

This is a upgrade to the RepRap Prusa. Becoming frustrated having to grab my pliers to level my bed, I invented this. This thing permanently holds the lock nut and also provides a tab to eliminate pliers.

When I printed the part, the opening was smaller than the nut. I solved this very carefully with a lighter. I gently heated the back of the lock nut and the plastic. I used the metal part of the lighter to push in the lock nut. The result was a solid lock nut with a convienient tab to adjust.

description.text:
Designed this phone cradle with funnels for speaker and mic. It actually plays very loud. I haven't tested to see of the mic funnel helps but I assume it will. My hopes were to be able to have the phone on speaker and be able to speak in a normal voice and still be able interact with the phone for browsing, working etc. This is the second thing I've really made with my printer. I learned a lot on how to design future things. I definitely learned that the use of arch bridges are the way to go. Keeping build angles to 45 deg is logical but I wonder what's the lowest practical limit I can do (maybe 30 degs ). I put support pillars as bridging support but the middle one broke off during the build because they are delicate just sticking up before the bridging reinforces it and ironically it broke during the bridging. I glued it back in place but the surface quality was shot. I might redesign this later on to be more universal for different phones and make it also more 3D printer friendly. As you can tell from one of the images I put mounting holes ( self explanatory ). Also the sound seems to be up to 3 times louder. I find myself lowering the volume often. Future Improvements:
1) Raise retaining walls
2) Use of arches instead of pillars
3) Direct Microphone funnel more in the direction of the phone
4) Add pockets for pens, etc [Optional]

comments.text:
I'll be using an ellipse or arch. I'll totally avoid any straight bridging and eliminating the pillars all together.. The Romans were onto something with these arches.
Before I actually update this design I'm going to do a little research and see if I can accommodate a larger line of phones. Sadly some phones have
their speaker on the front.
I would think smooth transitioning walls prevent echos and sound distortion. Anyhow I didn't want to over design it. I wanted to actually test it and hold it. You can only get so far in the virtual world. This was only the second item I've designed for my printer and I was eager to print things.
Thanks for your comments.
comments.author: daviepadilla

comments.text:
Ahh... now I get it... You mentioned arch bridges but I couldn't find one in this current design.
Sound wave energy is particularly sensitive to changes in area / volume along the pathway, while flat or curved walls, sharp changes in direction etc don't have much effect.
I don't know if frequency (?) distortion is even possible just from bouncing sound around..
I made one phone cradle / dock and considered a universal design... There are perhaps 5 popular sizes... Didn't pay attention to speaker or mic placement but would guess 75% of phones might be covered with 2 or 3 versions..
...but like you I'm more interested in printing things and quickly abandoned the effort ;-
comments.author: daviepadilla

comments.text:
wow.. This one's so pretty I had to d/load that huge file just to examine it in Blender. Very nice.
Regarding printer-friendliness, might you eliminate the support pillars altogether by removing the curved roof of the speaker cone? While ascetically appealing the gracefully curved roof can't be seen normally and I doubt the curve contributes greatly, if at all, to amplification.
According to my studies curved walls assist actual air movement but have little to no effect on sound wave propagation.
From your description it seems you can bridge that wide span without the pillars or support.... correct? Maybe I got his all wrong..

It's a small christmas tree with blinking lights to decorate your table with. 
For about $1 worth of components, you can have a merry table decoration that you can show off your 3D printing and electronics prowess with this year.
The tree has 16 holes for 5mm LEDs, room for the circuit and battery inside, with a switch in the base
Circuit design is included.
edit: Fixed some overhang issues and made holes a little bit bigger to more easily accommoate 5mm LEDs

Print both the base and the tree top.
I use Green ABS for the tree top, and brown ABS for the base. 10% fill will work fine. Either etch the PCB yourself, or get someone else to (alternatively, you could find another circuit and use that.) Included is a negative that you can make a transparency with whatever method you use. Drill 3mm holes for the 2 mounting screws. Use 0.8mm holes for everything else.
Assemble and solder the resistors, transistors and capacitors to the PCB as per the "PCB placement" diagram (make sure polarity of the capacitors is correct).
Make 4 strings of LED's as per the "LED strings" diagram. I mix the colours up a bit to make it interesting. Give yourself a decent length of wire between LEDs (about 4cm works) and 10-15cm leads on each end. Solder to the PCB. Solder a switch via short leads to the middle pair of pads. Note this should be soldered onto the solder side of the board so it can be mounted in the hole in the base for it.
Solder the battery clip to the other pair of pads (component side).
Screw switch into the base, then screw PCB onto base using M3 screws. Insert the LEDs into the holes in the tree top. I try and spread them round a bit so the blinking is a bit more distributed. Plug in battery, put the rest together and enjoy the show. Note: There are two blinking circuits in parallel which will get out of sync (depending on the variability in your components) which adds a nice 'random' blinking effect. You can change the rate of blinking by using different values for either the 1M resistors, or the capacitors (larger = slower). Try avoid using resistors over 1M if using BC547/8 transistors.

A completely over-engineered Quadcotper. I used the awesome Ardupilot 2.6. Some footage in flight: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SGJ_lMeXlz0 I used a cheap "action cam" to take the videos. The motor mounts contain 4 superbright leds each which are driven by one of the ESC's BEC output. I soldered the resistors for the leds into the channels in the motor mounts and then hotglued them tight. The cables go through the hollow arms. The body took 24 hours to print. I had to print it "upright", on its side since printing it flat always ended up in severe warping. Since I printed everything in Colorfabb XT I had to print quite slow as well ( 30 mm/s ). It was worth it though. I spray painted it black in the end. The arms are 10mm carbon fiber rods. Again a pain in the ass to get the screw holes to line up. Even with the attached harness ( armalignblock.stl ), it still didn't align perfectly and I had to force it into a somewhat correct orientation. The power distribution board is also of my design. The attached pdf contains all the layers. Its a double sided pcb, the XT-60 connector pins are soldered to one side each, and the ESC connectors are soldered on the top ( for positive ) and on the bottom ( for the negative ). Solder resist mask is highly recommended. All the screws are 3mm allen keys of various sizes. The landing gear is made from the same 10mm carbon rods. I used the awesome APM mount from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:252197 combined with the anti vibration mount from: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:160655 Other parts:
  • EMax BL2215/20 Motor
  • 10x5 APC prop and fitting spinner
  • AfroESC 20A
  • Spektrum AR6210 Receiver ( with satellite )
  • 4000mAh SLS Lipo
  • 8x Super Green ( 22000 Lumen ) Leds
  • 8x Super Red ( 18000 Lumen ) Leds
    • Flighttime is around 10-15 min. It looks absolutely awesome when flying at night, You can see the light on the ground even if its ~30m above the ground :) The take-off weight is about 1.5kg (with camera), and it can carry a payload of up to 1.3kg ( though above 600g it becomes impractical as you need 90% throttle just to lift off )

description.text:
Laser cut design for tilt /pan camera mount for kite photograpy.
Requires 2 micro servos, some tubing, and the ability to drill your own aluminum bracket for the camera. Designed to be hacker friendly. Almost any kind of wood or tubing can be used. Weight of prototype is 125 grams with servos and gears.

Almost any kind of plywood can be used. 2.5mm 5 ply was fragile but did work. I'm using 2 layers of 3mm plywood for the sides. 
The tubing can be 5/32 or 4mm. Ace hardware and other local hardware stores stock 5/32 tubing. 
The camera is attached by a thin bar of aluminum. The pivot point should be at the balance point for your camera. Make sure the arms are square to the bottom. 
The original files were made in inkscape. There are some weirdnesses in the DXF file, extra nodes that don't make sense. 
The hard part of this design is making sure that all edges are square to each other. You can either ignore twist, or start from one side, super gluing towards the other. 
The legs on the bottom can be extended by left over lengths of aluminum tube, or zip tied to a curve of PEX. A third leg can be added  in the back & connectd to two of the cross tubes.

description.text:
I want to turn a 15 litre water cooler bottle (the non-deposit kind made of of heavy pop bottle plastic) into a big freaking water rocket. This design is untested, use at your own risk. I for one don't plan on being anywhere near the launcher when I put pressure in. Just uploading it for comments/ideas. TODO:
-Release mechanism (in progress). The base design has spots for o-rings, and could operate by just letting it go whenever the pressure is stronger than the friction. I would like to add arms that lock on to a ring on the bottle later on, after I figure out if it will work at all.

Printing
======
The STL won't print as is: the two parts have to be seperated. I didn't think the hose barb would print well even with support unless it was vertical. It still needs work for overhangs. Build Thoughts
============
Probably needs to be printed with 30-60% infill with extra shells/perimeters and I plan on using ABS rather than PLA on this one. An acetone vapor treatment or a brush with acetone slurry might be a good idea to make sure it's air tight. The barb end is sized for 1/4" id air hose, but may need to be seperated: it's probably not going to print nicely that way. The rings on the riser should hold a set of O-Rings. They don't all need to be filled - just the 2 or 3 that the cap of the bottle touch against. The style of bottle I am using (see pictures) is smaller than the normal cooler bottles, and doesn't have a handle, so it should balance more easily. None the less, the legs of the launcher have holes to peg into the ground or screw onto a larger base. Potential issues
=============
  • The cap may completely pop off instead of launching from the smaller nozzle. Epoxy might help there.
  • I have no idea what kind of pressure these bottles can take. I plan on using just a little bit of water and building up
  • Balance and aim: the bottle will likely need some fins for stability and a nose cone for aerodynamics.
  • Need lots of space, probably bigger than a back yard. I don't want this thing hitting me or landing on anything I don't want damaged.

I think this desk lamp is one of those things that delivers on the promise of 3D printers to manufacture custom products to improve our lives  
My daughter hates the shadows cast by typical desk lamps, she hates the way they shine in her eyes, and she hates the heat given off by her halogen desk lamp.  So she set out to design something better for her odd-sized 52" long homework desk.  (It helped that it was an assignment for her class :)  
The lamp uses a strip of LEDs and 1/2" fiberglass tubing.  The self adhesive strip of LEDs are stuck to the top tube.  The wires are run inside the tubing and out of one of the mounting brackets.  The desk mounting brackets are designed to be a friction fit on the back corners of the desk.  
I have 2 pictures of her presentation in class with all of the classroom lights turned off.  (The class room tables are a different size than her desk, so she had to clamp it to the table in class.)  
This design should be generalizable to any table size by simply changing the length of the fiberglass tubes and the depth of the lip that goes under the table top.  If you would like to make one of these, let me know how thick your table top is, and I will make custom files for you.

You need one left mounting bracket, one right mounting bracket, and two of the right-angle connectors.  You need 4 pieces of 1/2" fiberglass tubing.  We got ours from TAP Plastics.  They are a little oversize, So the holes are as well.  I suppose aluminum tubing would work also.  
Put the mounting brackets on your desk and start cutting the tubing to fit.

title: T-rex Skeleton
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Update 2/21/15 - I have been focusing most of my free modeling time (which isn't much between work, my wife and four kids and their activities) lately on designing my steampunk cube gears (which can be seen here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:684376 ) and the upcoming steampunk version of the amazing gyroscopic cube gears which should be done reasonably soon. I have not forgotten about this model though. In fact, I have started taking it apart and working to make the individual pieces printable. I wanted to add a post here because while thinking about how to orient different pieces for printing, I had a fun thought about what I want to do with this model and started looking for references. I found a youtube video that shows pretty much exactly the type of thing I want to do with it here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UzBOvx5mP58 Making this a walking T-rex skeleton is going to be my next project after I finish the steampunk version of the amazing gyroscopic cube gears. If you look at my other moving creations, I think that it is reasonable to assume that it is something that I can accomplish. I have been doing some initial sketching and am excited to tackle this soon. Believe it or not, the hard part was doing all of the research and modeling. Making it move will be easy by comparison. I just wanted to share this update that I am excited about and will start posting the printable pieces for the moving dinosaur as I finish each section. More to come! Update 12/15 - I've been busy lately, so it has been a while since my last update. After doing more research on the bones in the tail, I realized that my original tail needed a lot of changes so I started over. I have added the new tail and am going to work on the skull next. Update 8/15 - I have added the spine to the pelvis region and down through most of the tail so far. I am still working on the details of the tail right now. I will post files later when they are more complete. Then on to the Skull. I had originally planned to use the Makerbot Academy skull, but after putting so much time into modeling this, I figured that I really should model my own skull. Update 7/6 - I have modeled the rough version of the spine, including the neck, back and ribs. I pushed past the limits that Sculptris will do in one model, so I started the spine in its own model. That won't hurt the final model however because I wanted to separate it into printable parts anyway. Like the other parts I have posted, I am posting the model here for show, but will be breaking it up into printable parts later after I have completed modeling the rest of the skeleton.
Update - I have added the pelvis, hip bone and I think its called Ilium? Again, these are rough versions of the bones that will likely be adjusted to scale some as the model progresses. Now on to the spine.
Update - I have completed the rough version of the legs. I will be adding more detail to them later.
When I saw the Makerbot Curriculum T-rex skull I was very impressed. Then I saw that they had the full printable skeleton and I actually said out loud "Awesome!!" as I stared wide eyed at the different pictures of it at the Makerbot Digital Store. I was ready to throw down my $15 and start printing until I saw a comment on the T-rex skull page that said the skeleton was in x3g file format???
Like may others I then went on a Google quest to find out what this strange file format was and how I could use it to print objects on my printer. After several hours of mining obscure forums and testing I stood defeated and crestfallen. I could not print their proprietary file format with my printer.
I decided to look upon this as an opportunity. I had been trying to decide what would be a good thing to design as my first real try with Sculptris and decided to call this inspiration instead. I am slowly working on designing a full T-rex skeleton to go with the excellent Curriculum Skull and make my T-rex printing dreams come true!
So far I have the two feet designed. Standing on the left foot and starting to lift the right foot. When I get the leg bones completed, I will design a mechanism to connect them, so please realize that these are a work in progress and the final versions will be different.
I will post updates as I add new files. The pictures are from Sculptris by the way. I will post pictures of prints as I create final versions.
I will post instructions as parts become ready to print.

comments.text: Joefe:  This is just fantastic!!  Please keep it up and give us the whole thing!  I can't believe that each bone is separate (separable with netfabb).  Amazing.  One constructive comment:  on the feet, I believe the dewclaw/hallux/first toe is not in the correct position.  Looking at museum specimens, there seems to be some disagreement about the exact position, but nearly all have it extended to the rear, and most rotated nearly 180 digress with the claw curving inward toward the sole.  I uploaded some pictures under "Made One."  Interestingly, SOME also seem to have one fewer bone.  Hmmmmmm.  But as I said, excellent work!
comments.author: bdipaolo

comments.text: I have been reading up more on the position of the hallux in tyrannosaurids and theropods in general, and it seems there is a large amount of disagreement and uncertainty.  The AMNH Tyrannosaurus is mounted with the hallices rotated to oppose the other digits (as in a perching bird), others like the Field Museum (Sue) have them extended to the rear but not rotated.  Still others have them extended medially.  I infer from this that the attachment marks on the metatarsal do not make the position of the hallux clear, so there is no right answer (until some more definitive footprint or other evidence is found).  I'm going to make one foot with the hallux in opposition and one not, just for fun!
comments.author: bdipaolo

comments.text: The compliments are well deserved.  Keep the files coming!  I am uploading a remix with the hallices extended to the rear but not rotated.  I printed one of yours and extended the hallux with the help of some epoxy, and I will upload a picture after it's painted.
comments.author: joefe

comments.text: Joefe:  On my "made one" page I have uploaded a picture of a Gorgosaurus fossil at the Royal Tyrrell Museum that is nearly complete and fully articulated and still partially encased in its matrix (very rare).  It appears to be pretty much in its original death position.  The feet are clearly visible including the hallices.  In particular the right foot has the hallux clearly visible and articulated.  It attaches to the second metatarsal about 2/3 of the way down, has only two bones besides the claw, and very clearly is NOT rotated so as to be opposable to the other toes.  Not a Tyrannosaurus, admittedly, but a fairly close relative, a "tyrannosaurid" more closely related to Albertosaurus.

We build things with pipes around here. Stair rails, hammock stands, whatever. That tends to leave ugly, harsh ends on the pipe. They collect dirt, attract pests. and are a pain to grab a hold of.  
This openscad file lets you set the inside & outside diameter of the pipe (because those are more likely to be known and easier to measure than the radii), and provides appropriate inner an outer flanges for the pipe.

I have a Prusa i1, and all the spool holders I could find have different measurements between top shafts or other issues. This is designed for 8mm rods, spaced 57mm centres. I have designed this to work for Vik's diamondage 125m Spools, based on 200mm full, and 90mm empty, the filament should not touch threaded rods, using Vik's spool holder and ABEC-9 skate bearings, super smooth filament feed is the goal. I drilled the centre of Vik's spool holders out to Ã˜14mm as the inner race was touching, providing some drag to the holder.

print, position spool above printhead, print better.
Revised, spool now sits 60mm further to the back, as testing indicated this is required (white arms in photograph).
Finished print (yellow arms in photograph) now working as expected!
(even though it looks a bit like its touching in the photo, the filament travels neatly in the middle of the two threaded rods, with no interference anywhere

author: huntclub

description.text: This is a substantial modification of the Horizontal Business Card Holder by Orias.  I made it more slim and added rounded corners and an inset for placing a 3d version of your logo or an initial.

I have a makerbot dual with one nozzle removed and have switched to printing entirely in PLA.  
It makes a difference what position you use to print and what slicer you use.  The top can be printed on its side with support in makerware or with the bottom up without support in repg.  The top looks great with 3d negatively extruded text in sketchup when printed from repg.
Skeinforge in repg does a much better job than miraclegrue in makerware, but the bottom needs to be printed with support in either case.  Miracle grue support comes out of the inset sloppily while repg support comes out much more cleanly.  When printing with repg and supports it also prints a raft and the raft is challenging to get off of the bottom.
Inset is 35mm x 35mm and 3.4 mm deep  
Sketchup files included.
**** 11/15 2012 Updated Top, the curves in the op seemed out of alignment in sketchup and print differently on each side.  New Top Sketchup file and new top stl file.
